p: We first described the ability of pulmonary epithelial type 2 (PTII) cells to synthesize androgens from SSPs in vitro using A549 cells. This PTII like cell line was established from a lung adenocarcinoma of an adult male. They have been widely used to study androgen metabolism ( 31– 34). As normal PTII cells, A549 cells can synthesize and secrete surfactant ( 11) and are androgen receptors (AR) positive ( 35). Our results show that A549 cells can rapidly convert androstenedione into testosterone with a little formation of 5α-DHT and the inactive 5α-androstane-3α,17β-diol ( 12). These cells show high levels of expression of 17β-HSD type 5 and 3α-HSD type 3. Overall, A549 cells present a high in vitro capacity of synthesizing and maintaining testosterone levels from SSPs while rapidly inactivating DHT ( 31).
